data.title: Battle of the Network Stars: Trump vs. Clinton
data.meta_description: The Republican and Democratic conventions will have an unusual job: rebooting two series we’ve been watching for decades.
data.text:
In a year of reboot culture — “Fuller House,” “The X-Files,” “Ghostbusters” — it was perhaps inevitable that we should get a reboot election.

Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump are unprecedented presumptive nominees: the first woman and the first reality-TV host to lead a major party ticket. But they’re also two people whom America has been watching for what seems like forever.

Mr. Trump became a household name in the days of “Dynasty,” and his tale has remained a kind of ’80s prime-time soap of aspiration and ego. Mrs. Clinton became a national figure in 1992, and ever since then her story has been a button-pushing serial about issues of power and gender.

Ordinarily, a nominating convention for a nonincumbent is about telling a new story. Not this year. For two weeks beginning July 18, Mr. Trump and Mrs. Clinton will each need to repackage a narrative that’s run longer than “Law & Order” into a brand-new, four-night mini-series.

Mr. Trump will go first. While it’s glib punditry to say that a nominee “needs to put on a show” at his convention, for him it amounts to proof of concept. He’s treated his showmanship as his chief qualification: Improvising meant he had good instincts; insulting opponents meant he was tough; shouting meant he wasn’t low-energy. In the primary, he cited his TV ratings the way another candidate might boast of balancing a state budget.
